If you insisted that every branch and segment be of exactly the same height and size, that would not be the marvelous hand of creation. You all need only go and cultivate innate knowing. If innate knowing is the same, it does not matter if there are differences. If you refuse to apply effort, you have not even produced a bamboo shoot yet—how can you discuss branches and segments?"

A local man with a father-son lawsuit came to present his case to the Master. An attendant wanted to block him, but the Master heard him out. Before the man had finished speaking, the father and son embraced each other, wept bitterly, and left.

Chai Mingzhi asked: "What did the Master say to bring about their remorse so quickly?"

The Master said: "I told them that Shun was the world's greatest unfilial son, and that the Blind Man was the world's most loving father."

Mingzhi was startled and asked for an explanation.

The Master said: "Shun always considered himself to be greatly unfilial, and therefore he was able to be filial. The Blind Man always considered himself to be greatly loving, and therefore he could not be loving. The Blind Man only remembered that he had raised Shun from infancy and thought: 'Why is he not pleasing me now?' He did not realize that his own mind had already been shifted by his second wife, yet still considered himself loving—which is why he became even less capable of love. Shun only thought of how his father loved him in infancy and thought: 'Now he does not love me—it must be that I cannot fully practice filial devotion.' Day by day he reflected on where he had failed in filial devotion, and therefore became ever more capable of it. When the Blind Man finally was pleased, it was nothing more than recovering the original substance of his originally loving mind. This is why later generations call Shun the greatest filial son of all time, and the Blind Man also became a loving father."

The Master said: "When Confucius had a common fellow come and ask him questions, he never began with prepared knowledge to respond. His mind was simply empty. He merely drew out the man's own sense of right and wrong on both sides, and gave him a clear resolution. The common fellow's mind was then fully clear. The common fellow's own sense of right and wrong is his original Heavenly principle. Even the sage, with all his brilliance, how could he add or subtract a hair from it? The man simply could not trust himself. Once Confucius gave him a clear resolution, the man's capacity was exhausted completely. If Confucius had retained any bit of his own knowledge when speaking with the common fellow, he would not have been able to exhaust the man's innate knowing, and the substance of the Way would have been split in two."

The Master said: "'Continuously guided, he did not go to the extreme of wickedness'—the traditional commentary says Xiang had already advanced toward righteousness and did not commit great wickedness. But after Shun was called to serve, Xiang still plotted daily to kill Shun—what great wickedness could surpass this! It was Shun who himself advanced in virtue and, through his virtue, gradually transformed Xiang. He did not go to correct Xiang's wickedness. In general, covering up faults and concealing evil is the common habit of bad people. If you try to point out their rights and wrongs, you will instead provoke their bad nature. When Shun first caused Xiang to want to kill him, it was also because his desire for Xiang's improvement was too urgent—this was Shun's own fault. Having gone through this experience, he then knew that the effort lies only in oneself, not in blaming others. This is how he achieved 'harmony.' This is where Shun 'stirred his mind, toughened his nature, and increased his capacities.' The ancients spoke from what they had personally gone through, which is why their words are so intimate and apt. Transmitted to later generations, they fit the circumstances of human feelings perfectly. If they had not personally gone through it, how could they have reached such depth of heartfelt understanding?"

The Master said: "Ancient music has not been performed for a long time. Today's theatrical performances still come close to the spirit of ancient music."

Not understanding, someone asked for an explanation.

The Master said: "The nine movements of the Shao music were simply a theatrical performance of Shun's life story. The nine variations of the Wu music were simply a theatrical performance of King Wu's life story. The actual deeds of the sages' entire lives were all set forth in their music. That is why those of virtue, upon hearing it, could tell whether it was 'perfectly beautiful and perfectly good' or 'perfectly beautiful but not perfectly good.' If later ages composed music that was merely arranging words and tunes, with absolutely no connection to the customs and moral transformation of the people, how could it transform the people toward goodness? If today we want folk customs to return to simplicity and genuineness, take today's theatrical performances and remove all the licentious and depraved songs. Keep only the stories of loyal ministers and filial sons, making them easily understood by the common, unlettered people. Without their realizing it, their innate knowing will be stirred—and this would benefit moral transformation. Then ancient music could gradually be restored."

Someone said: "Dehong has sought the primal sound but cannot find it. I fear ancient music is also difficult to restore."

The Master said: "Where do you think the primal sound is to be sought?"

He replied: "The ancients made pitch-pipes to test the vital energy—that was perhaps the method for seeking the primal sound."

The Master said: "If you try to seek the primal sound in reed ashes and millet grains, it is like scooping the moon from the bottom of a pond—how can you succeed? The primal sound can only be sought in your own mind."

He asked: "How does one seek it in the mind?"

The Master said: "The ancients in governing first nourished the minds of the people into harmony and balance, and only then made music. For example, singing poetry here: if your mind and vital energy are harmonious and balanced, listeners will naturally feel pleased and uplifted. This itself is the beginning of the primal sound. The Book of Documents says 'Poetry expresses aspirations'—aspirations are the root of music. 'Song elongates words'—song is the root of making music. 'Tones follow the elongation, and pitch-pipes harmonize the tones'—pitch-pipes only need to harmonize with the tones, and harmonizing with tones is the root of establishing the pitch-pipes. When has it ever been sought externally?"

He asked: "What was the intent of the ancients' method of testing vital energy with pitch-pipes?"

The Master said: "The ancients, possessing the substance of centrality and harmony, made music. My own centrality and harmony is originally in resonance with the vital energy of Heaven and Earth. Testing the vital energy of Heaven and Earth and matching it with the tones of the phoenix was merely to verify whether my own vital energy was truly harmonious. This is something done after the pitch-pipes were already established, not something needed to establish them in the first place. If today you want to test the vital energy with ash-filled tubes, you must first determine the solstice. But the exact moment of the solstice is likely imprecise—so where would you get anything precise from?"

The Master said: "Learning also needs someone to point out the way. But this is not as good as when one breaks through on one's own, for then everything is settled at once. Otherwise, no amount of pointing will suffice."

"Confucius' scope of spirit was immense. All the enterprises of emperors and kings—there was none he did not thoroughly comprehend. Yet all of it came from that mind. It is like a great tree with ever so many branches and leaves—all because the effort of cultivation was applied at the root. Naturally it can be so. It is not that by working on the branches and leaves one can build a root. When learners study Confucius, if they do not apply effort on the mind but anxiously try to learn his scope of spirit, they are doing it in reverse."
"When people have faults, if they devote their effort to the fault itself, it is like mending a broken pot—the inevitable result is covering up the fault."

"People today, even when eating a meal with nothing else before them, find their minds restless and unsettled. This is only because the mind has become habituated to busyness, so it cannot be collected."
"The lute, the zither, and books—a learner cannot do without these. For when one has an occupation to dwell in, the mind will not run wild."

The Master sighed: "Among those in the world who know about learning, only this ailment cannot be broken through. That itself shows one is not good at doing good together with others."

Chongyi said: "This ailment is merely the desire for loftiness and the inability to forget oneself."

Someone asked: "Innate knowing is originally a state of equilibrium and harmony. How then can there be excess and deficiency?"

The Master said: "Knowing where there is excess and deficiency—that itself is equilibrium and harmony."
"'What one dislikes in those above'—that is innate knowing. 'Not using it to employ those below'—that is extending innate knowing."

The Master said: "The intelligence of Su Qin and Zhang Yi was also the raw material of sages. The achievements and writings of many great heroes and renowned thinkers of later ages were merely learned imitations of Su and Zhang's strategic intelligence. Su and Zhang's technique excelled at reading people's feelings—there was not the slightest point where it failed to touch the vital spot. That is why their persuasive arguments were inexhaustible. Su and Zhang also glimpsed the marvelous function of innate knowing—they simply applied it to what was not good."

Someone asked about "before arousal" and "after arousal."

The Master said: "It is only because later Confucians split 'before arousal' and 'after arousal' into two separate things that I must bluntly say there is no such split between before-arousal and after-arousal, to make people think it through themselves. If I said there is a before-arousal and after-arousal, listeners would just fall back into the later Confucians' interpretation. If one truly sees that there is no split between before-arousal and after-arousal, then saying there is a before-arousal and after-arousal does no harm—there originally is a before-arousal and after-arousal present."

Someone further asked: "Before arousal is never without harmony; after arousal is never without centrality. It is like a bell: before it is struck, one cannot say it has no sound; when struck, one cannot say it has sound. But ultimately there is a difference between struck and not struck—what about this?"

The Master said: "Before being struck, it is already earth-shaking. When struck, it is utterly silent and still."

Someone asked: "The ancients all had different views on the nature. Which is the definitive theory?"

The Master said: "The nature has no fixed form, and theorizing about it also has no fixed form. Some speak from the perspective of the original substance; some from the perspective of its function and manifestation; some from its source; some from its degenerate forms. In sum, it is all just one nature—the difference lies only in the depth of understanding. If you fix on one side, it is wrong. The original substance of the nature is originally without good or evil. In its function and manifestation, it is originally capable of being good or not good. In its degenerate forms, it is naturally fixedly good or fixedly evil. It is like the eye: there is the eye when joyful, the eye when angry; looking straight ahead is the seeing eye, glancing sideways is the peering eye. In sum, it is all just this one eye. If upon seeing the angry eye you say there was never a joyful eye, or upon seeing the seeing eye you say there was never a peering eye—all of this is fixation, and you know it is wrong. When Mencius discussed the nature, he spoke directly from its source, also stating only the general principle. Xunzi's theory that the nature is evil speaks from the perspective of degenerate forms. It cannot be said that he is entirely wrong—he simply did not see deeply enough. Common people have lost the original substance of the mind."

Someone said: "Mencius, speaking of the nature from its source, wanted people to apply effort at the source and see clearly there. Xunzi, speaking of the nature from its degenerate forms, could only apply effort to correct things at the downstream end, which is more laborious."

The Master said: "Indeed."

The Master said: "When effort reaches the most refined level, words become increasingly inadequate, and speaking of principle becomes increasingly difficult. If one deliberately focuses on the subtle and refined, the effort of the whole substance is instead obscured and muddied."
"Yang Cihu was not without insight, but he became fixed on perceiving things at the level of 'no sound and no smell.'"

"In a single day, a person passes through all the ages of the world, only people do not notice. In the clarity of the night air, when there is no seeing, no hearing, no thinking, no acting, with a calm and level mind—that is the world of Emperor Fu Xi. At dawn, when the spirit is clear and the vital energy bright, with a dignified and harmonious bearing—that is the world of Yao and Shun. Before midday, when propriety and ceremony are exchanged, with an orderly atmosphere—that is the world of the Three Dynasties. After midday, when the spirit and vital energy gradually grow dim, with comings and goings in confusion—that is the world of the Spring and Autumn and Warring States periods. Gradually entering the darkness of night, when all things rest in sleep and the scene is desolate—that is the world where humanity has perished and things are exhausted. If a learner can fully trust innate knowing and not be disordered by the vital energy, he will always be a person of the age before Fu Xi."

Xue Shangqian, Zou Qianzhi, Ma Zicui, and Wang Ruzhi were seated in attendance. They sighed that since the Master's campaign against the Prince of Ning, criticisms from across the realm had increased. They each offered their explanations. One said the Master's achievements and position were daily growing greater, so those in the world who envied him were also daily increasing. One said the Master's learning was daily becoming clearer, so those who disputed with the Song Confucians' position were also daily more numerous. One said that after the Master left Nanjing, those who believed and followed him among like-minded friends were daily increasing, and therefore those in all directions who opposed him were also pressing harder.

The Master said: "What you all say is indeed the case. But there is one thing I know about myself that none of you has touched upon."

The friends asked what it was.

The Master said: "Before I was in Nanjing, I still had somewhat of the 'village worthy's' disposition. Now I have come to trust that this innate knowing is truly right and truly wrong. I act freely according to it, without the slightest concealment. Now I have finally achieved the broad-mindedness of the 'wild.' Let all the people in the world say that my actions are not hidden behind my words—that is fine."

Shangqian came forward and said: "To fully trust this—that is the true lifeblood of the sage."

The Master's way of tempering people could move them most deeply with a single word. One day, Wang Ruzhi returned from an outing.

The Master asked: "What did you see on your outing?"

He replied: "I saw that everyone in the streets is a sage."

The Master said: "You see everyone in the streets as a sage, and everyone in the streets sees you as a sage."

On another day, Dong Luoshi returned from an outing.

Seeing the Master, he said: "Today I saw something extraordinary."

The Master said: "What was extraordinary?"

He replied: "I saw that everyone in the streets is a sage."

The Master said: "This is quite ordinary—what is extraordinary about it?"

The reason is that Ruzhi's sharp edges were not yet smoothed, while Luoshi had a sudden flash of insight. Therefore though the question was the same, the answers were different—each was given the reverse of his own words to advance him.

Dehong, together with Huang Zhengzhi, Zhang Shuqian, and Ruzhong, returned from the metropolitan examination in the bingxu year (1526). They told the Master about lecturing on the Way during their travels, and how some believed and some did not.

The Master said: "You took a sage along to lecture to people. When people see a sage coming, they all run away in fear—how can you lecture? You must make yourself an ordinary man or woman before you can lecture to people."

Dehong also said that today it is very easy to see the quality of people.

The Master said: "How do you see it?"

He replied: "The Master is like Mount Tai standing before us. Anyone who does not know to look up must be a person without eyes."

The Master said: "Mount Tai is not as great as level ground. What is there to see on level ground?"

With a single stroke the Master cut away and exposed the lifelong ailment of those present who sought external loftiness. All those seated were startled and chastened.

In the spring of the guiwei year (1523), Zou Qianzhi came to Yue to study. After staying for several days, the Master saw him off at Floating Peak. That evening, with Xiyuan and other friends, they moved their boat to stay at Yanshou Temple. Holding candles and sitting through the night, the Master was deeply moved and sighing.

He said: "The river waves and misty willows—our old friend is suddenly a hundred li away!"

A friend asked: "Why does the Master think of Qianzhi so deeply?"

The Master said: "What Zengzi described as 'able yet asking the unable, having much yet asking those with little, having as if not having, full as if empty, offended yet not retaliating'—Qianzhi comes close to this."

In the ninth month of the dinghai year (1527), the Master was recalled to service for the campaign against Si'en and Tianzhou. Just as he was about to set out, Dehong and Ruzhong discussed the teaching together.

Ruzhong cited the Master's instruction: "Having no good and no evil is the substance of the mind. Having good and having evil is the movement of the intention. Knowing good and knowing evil is innate knowing. Doing good and removing evil is the investigation of things."

Dehong asked: "What is the meaning of this?"

Ruzhong said: "I fear this is not yet the ultimate formulation. If we say the substance of the mind is without good or evil, then the intention is also without good or evil, knowing is also without good or evil, and things are also without good or evil. If we say the intention has good and evil, then ultimately the substance of the mind still has good and evil in it."

Dehong said: "The substance of the mind is the nature decreed by Heaven—it is originally without good or evil. But because people have habitual minds, good and evil are seen in the intentions. The efforts of investigation, extension, sincerity, rectification, and cultivation are precisely the work of recovering that nature. If there were originally no good or evil, there would be no need to speak of effort at all."

That evening, they attended the Master at the Tianquan Bridge and each presented his view for correction.

The Master said: "I am about to depart, and I precisely need you both to come and clarify this. The views of you two are exactly suited to complement each other—you must not each hold to one side alone. In my approach to teaching, there have always been these two kinds. For those of sharp capacity, I point them directly to realization from the source. The original substance of the human mind is originally bright, clear, and unobstructed—it is the original state of equilibrium before arousal. For those of sharp capacity, once they awaken to the original substance, that is the effort itself—self and others, inner and outer, are all penetrated at once. For the next level, they inevitably have habitual minds, and the original substance is obscured. So I teach them first to earnestly do good and remove evil at the level of intentions. When the effort matures and the dregs are entirely removed, the original substance also becomes fully bright. Ruzhong's view is my approach for those of sharp capacity. Dehong's view is my method established for the next level. If you two complement each other, then people of all levels—above and below average—can all be guided into the Way. If each holds to one side, you will immediately lose people before you, and the substance of the Way will not be fully expressed in either case."

He then said: "Hereafter, in lecturing with friends, you must not lose my fundamental teaching. Having no good and no evil is the substance of the mind. Having good and having evil is the movement of the intention. Knowing good and knowing evil is innate knowing. Doing good and removing evil is the investigation of things. Simply follow this formulation and guide people according to their capacity—there will be no fault. This is originally an effort that penetrates from top to bottom. People of truly sharp capacity are rare in the world. To awaken at once to the original substance and have the effort of the original substance completely penetrate—this is what Yan Hui and Cheng Hao did not dare to claim for themselves. How can one lightly hope for this in others? People have habitual minds. If you do not teach them to earnestly apply the effort of doing good and removing evil on the level of innate knowing, and merely have them imagine the original substance in empty abstraction, with all their practical affairs having no substance—this only cultivates an empty stillness. This ailment is not a minor one, and it must be clearly stated early on."

That day, both Dehong and Ruzhong had a realization.

When the Master first returned to Yue, the traces of friends coming were still few. Afterwards, those coming from all directions to study increased daily. After the guiwei year (1523), those who settled around the Master filled house after house. At the temples of Tianfei, Guangxiang, and others, each room regularly had several dozen people eating together. At night there was no room to sleep, so they took turns using the beds, and the sound of singing continued from dusk to dawn. At Nanzhen, the Cave of Yu, Yangming Cave, and other mountain temples near and far, wherever one's feet could reach, there were fellow students lodging. Whenever the Master took his seat to lecture, those sitting in a circle to listen, in front, behind, left, and right, were regularly no fewer than several hundred. Seeing off the departing and welcoming the arriving, there was not a single idle day in the month. There were even those who stayed in attendance for over a year, and whose names could not all be remembered.

Whenever a parting came, the Master would often sigh: "Although you are departing, you do not leave Heaven and Earth. If we share this same aspiration, I too can be at ease in spirit even though separated in body."

Whenever students left after a lecture, they invariably leapt and exclaimed with delight. I have heard from senior fellows of the same school: "Before Nanjing, although many friends followed and studied with the Master, none could match the flourishing at Yue. Although this is partly because the longer he lectured the more his credibility spread, it is also because the Master's own learning was daily advancing. The power of his influence to inspire underwent transformations beyond measure—there was naturally something different about it."

The following is recorded by Huang Yifang.

Huang Yifang asked: "If 'broad learning in culture' means learning to preserve the Principle of Heaven in every situation, then the statement 'if there is energy left over, study culture' seems not to agree with it."

The Master said: "The Odes, Documents, and Six Arts are all manifestations of the Principle of Heaven—'culture' includes all of them. Studying the Odes, Documents, and Six Arts is all part of learning to preserve this Principle of Heaven. It is not only what manifests in practical conduct that constitutes 'culture.' 'Studying culture with leftover energy' is also just one aspect of 'broad learning in culture.'"

Someone asked about the two sentences: "Learning without thinking" and "thinking without learning."

The Master said: "This was said in response to a particular context. In reality, thinking is learning. When there are doubts in one's learning, one must think them through. Those who 'think without learning' are people of this type: they merely think in empty abstraction, wanting to work out a principle by thinking alone, yet do not apply real effort on body and mind to learn and preserve this Principle of Heaven. They make thinking and learning two separate activities, which is why there are the ailments of 'bewilderment' and 'peril.' In reality, thinking is just thinking about what one is learning—they are not originally two things."

The Master said: "The earlier Confucians interpreted 'investigation of things' as investigating all the things in the world. How can all the things in the world be investigated? Moreover, they said even a single blade of grass or tree has its principle—how would you go about investigating that? Even if you could investigate grass and trees, how would that serve to make your own intentions sincere? My interpretation is: 'investigation' means 'rectification,' and 'things' means 'affairs.'

What the Great Learning calls 'the body' refers to the ears, eyes, mouth, nose, and four limbs. To cultivate the body means: the eyes must not look at what is contrary to propriety, the ears must not listen to what is contrary to propriety, the mouth must not speak what is contrary to propriety, the four limbs must not do what is contrary to propriety. To cultivate this body—how can effort be applied on the body itself? The mind is the master of the body. Although the eyes see, what does the seeing is the mind. Although the ears hear, what does the hearing is the mind. Although the mouth and limbs speak and move, what does the speaking and moving is the mind. Therefore, to cultivate the body lies in personally realizing one's own mind-substance, keeping it constantly vast and impartial, without the slightest lack of correctness. When the master is correct, then what issues through the eyes will naturally have no improper seeing; what issues through the ears will naturally have no improper hearing; what issues through the mouth and limbs will naturally have no improper speaking or moving. This is 'cultivating the body lies in rectifying the mind.' But the highest good is the original substance of the mind—how could the mind's original substance have anything not good?

Since we now want to rectify the mind, where on the original substance can effort be applied? It must be at the point where the mind is activated—only there can one apply effort. The mind's activation cannot be without what is not good. Therefore one must apply effort at this point—and that is 'making the intentions sincere.' For example: when a thought arises directed toward loving good, one genuinely and solidly goes and loves good. When a thought arises directed toward hating evil, one genuinely and solidly goes and hates evil. When the intentions, as they arise, are without any insincerity, then how could the original substance be incorrect? Therefore, to rectify the mind lies in making the intentions sincere. The effort, when it reaches 'making the intentions sincere,' first has a place of real application.

But the root of making the intentions sincere lies further in the extension of knowledge. What is called 'what others do not know but one alone knows'—this is precisely the place of one's mind's innate knowing. Yet if, knowing what is good, one does not follow this innate knowing and act on it; or knowing what is not good, one does not follow this innate knowing and refrain from it—then this innate knowing is obscured. This is the failure to extend knowledge. If one's mind's innate knowing cannot be extended to its fullest, then although one knows good, one cannot genuinely love it; although one knows evil, one cannot genuinely hate it. How can the intentions be made sincere? Therefore the extension of knowledge is the root of making the intentions sincere.

Yet it is not an abstract extension of knowledge. The extension of knowledge lies in the investigation of things in actual practice. When the intention is directed toward doing good, one goes and does it in this particular matter. When the intention is directed toward removing evil, one goes and refrains from it in this particular matter. Removing evil is certainly rectifying what is incorrect to return it to correctness. But doing good—when what was not yet correct becomes correct—is also rectifying what is incorrect to return it to correctness.

Thus, one's mind's innate knowing, no longer obscured by selfish desires, can be extended to its utmost. And the intentions, as they arise, in loving good and removing evil, will be without any insincerity. The actual starting point of the effort of making the intentions sincere is the investigation of things. If one investigates things in this way, everyone can do it. That all people can become Yao and Shun—this is precisely the point."

The Master said: "Everyone just says that for 'investigation of things' one must follow Zhu Xi. But has anyone actually taken his explanation and put it into practice? I genuinely tried to put it into practice. In my early years, together with my friend Qian, we discussed how to become sages and worthies. We were to investigate all the things in the world—but how could we muster such immense energy? I pointed to the bamboo in front of the pavilion and told him to try investigating it. Qian went day and night to exhaustively investigate the principle of the bamboo, exhausting his mental energy. By the third day, he had strained his mind to the point of falling ill. At first I said his vital energy was insufficient. So I went to investigate it myself, day and night unable to find any principle. By the seventh day, I too fell ill from exhausting my thoughts. We then sighed to each other that becoming a sage or worthy was impossible—we lacked the great energy to investigate things. It was only during my three years among the barbarians that I came to see the meaning of this clearly. I then knew that among all the things in the world, there is originally nothing to be investigated externally. The effort of investigating things lies only in the work on one's own body and mind. I then firmly concluded that sagehood is something everyone can attain, and from then on had the confidence to take it on. I want to share this understanding with all of you."

A disciple mentioned that Shao Duanfeng argued that children cannot investigate things, and should only be taught sweeping, receiving guests, and responding to elders.

The Master said: "Sweeping and responding to guests is itself a 'thing.' A child's innate knowing only reaches this far, so teaching them to sweep and respond to guests is precisely extending this single point of innate knowing. Also, for example, a child knows to respect his teacher and elders—this too is a point of innate knowing. Therefore, even in the midst of play, upon seeing a teacher or elder, the child goes and bows respectfully. This is the child investigating things to extend the innate knowing of respecting teachers and elders. Children naturally have their own level of investigation of things and extension of knowledge."

He further said: "What I mean by investigation of things applies the same effort from children to sages. It is just that the sage's investigation of things is more practiced and requires less exertion. This kind of investigation of things—even a firewood seller can do it. And from high ministers and officials up to the emperor himself, all do it in the same way."

Someone doubted that knowledge and action are not unified, and raised the two sentences 'knowing is not difficult' as a question.

The Master said: "Innate knowing itself knows—it is originally easy. It is simply that one cannot extend that innate knowing into practice. That is what is meant by 'knowing is not difficult; acting is truly difficult.'"

A disciple asked: "How can knowledge and action be unified? For example, the Doctrine of the Mean speaks of 'broad learning' and also of 'earnest practice'—clearly knowledge and action are two things."

The Master said: "Broad learning simply means learning in all things to preserve this Principle of Heaven. Earnest practice simply means the intention of not ceasing to learn."

He further asked: "The Changes says 'learning to gather' and also 'humaneness to practice.' How is this?"

The Master said: "It is the same. Learning in all things to preserve this Principle of Heaven means this mind will never be lost. Therefore it says 'learning to gather.' But constantly learning to preserve this Principle of Heaven without any interruption by selfish desire—this is where the mind never rests. Therefore it says 'humaneness to practice.'"

He further asked: "Confucius says 'knowledge reaches it, but humaneness cannot hold it.' Doesn't that make knowledge and action two things?"

The Master said: "When it says 'reaching it,' one is already acting. But being unable to practice constantly, since selfish desires interrupt—that is 'humaneness cannot hold it.'"

He further asked: "Regarding the teaching that 'the mind is principle,' Cheng Yi said 'in things there is principle.' How then can one say the mind is principle?"

The Master said: "'In things there is principle'—the character 'in' should have the character 'mind' added before it. This mind being in things is principle. For example, this mind being in serving one's father is filial devotion; this mind being in serving one's ruler is loyalty—and so on."

The Master then said to them: "You must all understand the fundamental purpose of my teaching. When I now say 'the mind is principle,' how is that so? It is only because people in the world split the mind and principle into two, which creates many ailments. Like the Five Hegemons, whose actions of repelling the barbarians and honoring the Zhou court were all from a private mind—these did not accord with principle. Yet people say their actions accorded with principle, saying only that their minds were not pure. People often admire and want to imitate what they did, wanting to make things look good on the outside, yet it has nothing to do with the mind at all. Splitting the mind and principle into two, the result ultimately reaches the falseness of the Hegemons' way without one even being aware of it. Therefore my saying 'the mind is principle' is to make people know that mind and principle are one. Then they will apply effort on the mind and not borrow righteousness from outside—and that is the truth of the Kingly Way. This is the fundamental purpose of my teaching."

He further asked: "The sages and worthies said so many things—why must you make them all into one?"

The Master said: "I am not trying to force them into one. As it says: 'The Way is one and that is all.' And: 'Its substance being without duality, its production of things is unfathomable.' Heaven, Earth, and the sages are all one. How can they be made two?"

"The mind is not a lump of flesh and blood. Wherever there is awareness and perception, that is the mind. For example, the awareness of seeing and hearing in the ears and eyes, the awareness of pain and itch in the hands and feet—this awareness and perception is the mind."

Yifang asked: "According to the Master's teaching on 'investigation of things,' the 'watchful solitude' of the Doctrine of the Mean, 'accumulating righteousness,' and 'breadth and restraint' are all matters of 'investigation of things.'"

The Master said: "No. Investigation of things is watchful solitude, is vigilance and apprehension. As for 'accumulating righteousness' and 'breadth and restraint,' the effort is the same throughout. It is not that those several things are all subsumed under the category of 'investigation of things.'"

Yifang asked about the passage on "honoring the virtuous nature."

The Master said: "'Pursuing inquiry and study' is precisely the way to 'honor the virtuous nature.' Zhu Xi said that Lu Xiangshan instructed people by 'honoring the virtuous nature,' while he himself perhaps placed somewhat too much emphasis on 'pursuing inquiry and study.' This splits 'honoring the virtuous nature' and 'pursuing inquiry and study' into two things. Consider: all the effort we now put into discussion and study is nothing but preserving this mind and not losing its virtuous nature. How could 'honoring the virtuous nature' be merely honoring in empty abstraction, with no inquiry or study? And how could 'inquiry and study' be merely empty inquiry and study with no connection to the virtuous nature? If that were so, then I do not know what today's discussion and study are actually learning."

Someone asked about the two sentences "achieving breadth" and "exhausting refinement."

The Master said: "'Exhausting refinement' is precisely the way to 'achieve breadth.' 'Following the middle way' is precisely the way to 'reach the lofty and brilliant.' For the original substance of the mind is naturally broad. If a person cannot 'exhaust refinement,' then selfish desires will obscure it, and it becomes exceedingly small. Therefore, if one can attend to every fine and subtle turn, leaving nothing unexhausted, then selfish intentions cannot obscure it. There will naturally be no obstructions or separations—how could breadth not be achieved?"

He further asked: "Is this 'refinement' the refinement of thoughts, or the refinement of the principles of things?"

The Master said: "The refinement of thoughts is the refinement of the principles of things."

The Master said: "Today's theorists on human nature, with all their agreements and disagreements, are all merely talking about the nature—none of them have actually seen the nature. For one who has truly seen it, there is nothing left to agree or disagree about."

Someone asked: "As for sounds, sights, wealth, and profit—I fear that even innate knowing cannot be without them."

The Master said: "Indeed. But for beginners applying effort, one must sweep and wash them all away, not letting any accumulate. Then when they come naturally upon one, they will not be a burden, and one can respond to them with natural ease. Innate knowing applies its effort precisely on sounds, sights, wealth, and profit. If one can make innate knowing refined, clear, and bright, without the slightest obscuration, then the encounters with sounds, sights, wealth, and profit are nothing but the flowing of the Heavenly principle."

The Master said: "In my lectures with all of you on 'extension of knowledge' and 'investigation of things,' day after day it is the same. Even after lecturing for ten or twenty years, it would still be the same. If you listen to my words and truly go apply the effort, you will feel that with each lecture, you advance a step further. Otherwise, you merely treat it as a topic of conversation—what use is listening?"

The Master said: "The original substance of the human being is always in a state of tranquil immobility, and is always in a state of being stirred to penetrating response. Before responding is not 'before,' and after responding is not 'after.'"

A friend raised the following: "A Buddhist pointed out his finger and asked: 'Do you all see this?' They said: 'We see it.' He then put his finger back into his sleeve and asked: 'Do you still see it?' They said: 'We do not see it.' The Buddha said: 'You have not yet seen your nature.' The meaning of this is unclear to me."

The Master said: "The finger may be seen or not seen, but your nature of seeing is always present. People's mind-spirits gallop only after what is seen and heard, and do not earnestly apply effort on what is not seen and not heard. For what is not seen and not heard is the original substance of innate knowing. Vigilance and apprehension are the effort of extending innate knowing. The learner must at all times constantly see what is not seen and constantly hear what is not heard—only then does the effort have a solid foundation. After long maturation, one no longer needs to exert effort or maintain vigilance, and the true nature will naturally never cease. How could what is externally seen and heard be a burden?"

Someone asked: "The earlier Confucians said that 'the kite flying' and 'fish leaping,' together with 'there must be this matter,' share the same vibrant vitality."

The Master said: "Indeed. The vibrant vitality between Heaven and Earth is nothing but this principle, which is the ceaseless flow of my innate knowing. 'Extending innate knowing' is precisely the effort of 'there must be this matter.' This principle cannot be departed from—indeed, it cannot actually be departed from. There is nowhere that is not the Way, and nowhere that is not the effort."

The Master said: "All of you who are here must establish the resolve to definitely become sages. At every moment, you must be as if each stroke of the rod leaves a welt and each slap draws blood—only then can you hear my words and have each sentence take hold. If you just drift aimlessly through the days, you are like a piece of dead meat that does not feel the rod's pain. I fear in the end nothing will come of it, and when you go home you will just pick up your old tricks again. Would that not be a pity?"

Someone asked: "Recently I feel that deluded thoughts have decreased, and I also feel that I have not been deliberately setting out to apply any particular effort. Could this be the proper effort?"

The Master said: "You should go and honestly apply effort. Even if there is a bit more deliberate intention in it, that does no harm. In time it will naturally settle into place. If you have barely begun the effort and already talk about results, what reliance is that?"

A friend lamented to himself: "When selfish thoughts sprout, I clearly know it in my own mind. But I simply cannot make them go away immediately."

The Master said: "The knowing at the moment of sprouting—that is your lifeline. To immediately dissolve them at that moment—that is the effort of establishing one's destiny."

"When Confucius said 'natures are close to one another,' he meant the same thing as Mencius' 'the nature is good'—one should not interpret this exclusively in terms of the material endowment. If one speaks of the material endowment, then rigid and yielding are opposites—how could they be 'close'? Only because the nature is good are they the same. At birth, people's goodness is originally the same. But those who are rigid: if they become habituated to good, they become rigidly good; if habituated to evil, they become rigidly evil. Those who are yielding: if habituated to good, they become yieldingly good; if habituated to evil, they become yieldingly evil. Thus they daily grow further apart."

The Master once said to his students: "On the mind's substance, not a single thought may be allowed to linger, just as the eye cannot tolerate even a grain of sand. How much can a grain of sand be? Yet the whole eye becomes blind and dark."

He further said: "This lingering thought is not just private thoughts—even good thoughts must not be allowed to linger. It is like putting gold or jade dust in the eye—the eye still cannot open."

Someone asked: "The human mind is one body with things. Within my own body, the blood and vital energy flow freely—that is why it is called one body. But with other people it is already a different body. And with birds, beasts, grass, and trees, it is even more distant! How can they be called one body?"

The Master said: "You need only look at the mechanism of stimulus and response. Not only birds, beasts, grass, and trees—even Heaven and Earth are one body with me, and ghosts and spirits are one body with me."

The questioner asked for an explanation.

The Master said: "Look at what is the mind of Heaven and Earth in their midst."

He replied: "I have heard it said that the human being is the mind of Heaven and Earth."

The Master said: "And what is it in the human being that is called the mind?"

He replied: "It is simply the single point of spiritual clarity."

The Master said: "Then you can know that filling all of Heaven and Earth, there is only this spiritual clarity. It is just that the physical form creates a separation for people. My spiritual clarity is the lord of Heaven, Earth, and ghosts and spirits. If Heaven did not have my spiritual clarity, who would look up at its height? If Earth did not have my spiritual clarity, who would look down into its depth? If ghosts and spirits did not have my spiritual clarity, who would discern their fortune, misfortune, disaster, and auspiciousness? If Heaven, Earth, ghosts, spirits, and the myriad things were separated from my spiritual clarity, there would be no Heaven, Earth, ghosts, spirits, or myriad things. And if my spiritual clarity were separated from Heaven, Earth, ghosts, spirits, and the myriad things, there would be no spiritual clarity either. Thus it is all one vital energy flowing through—how could there be any separation?"

Someone further asked: "Heaven, Earth, ghosts, spirits, and the myriad things have existed since antiquity. How can it be that without my spiritual clarity, they would all cease to exist?"

The Master said: "Consider a dead person—his spiritual essence has dispersed. Where then are his Heaven, Earth, and myriad things?"

The Master set out on the campaign against Si'en and Tianzhou. Dehong and Ruzhong followed to see him off as far as Yantan. Ruzhong raised the Buddhist distinction between "real appearances" and "illusory appearances."

The Master said: "With mind, all is real. Without mind, all is illusory. Without mind, all is real. With mind, all is illusory."

Ruzhong said: "'With mind all is real, without mind all is illusory' speaks of the effort from the perspective of the original substance. 'Without mind all is real, with mind all is illusory' speaks of the original substance from the perspective of the effort."

The Master agreed with his words.

Dehong at that time still did not fully comprehend. Only after several years of effort did he come to trust in the unity of original substance and effort. But the Master at that time spoke of it only casually in response to a question. In our Confucian way of guiding people, it is not necessary to borrow such terms to establish one's teaching.

Once, the Master was seen off two or three elderly scholars at the gate. Returning, he sat in the central hall, and seemed to have a worried expression. Dehong hurried forward to ask.

The Master said: "Just now, discussing this learning with the elders, it was truly like putting a round peg in a square hole. This Way is as smooth and open as a highway, yet the common Confucians keep adding brambles and thorns to it. They spend their entire lives stuck in a thicket of thorns without remorse—I do not know what to say about it!"

Dehong withdrew and told the friends: "The Master instructs people without discriminating between young and old. This is the humane person's heart of compassion for all."

The Master said: "The greatest ailment of human life is a single word: arrogance. As a son, if arrogant, one will certainly not be filial. As a minister, if arrogant, one will certainly not be loyal. As a father, if arrogant, one will certainly not be loving. As a friend, if arrogant, one will certainly not be trustworthy. Thus Xiang and Danzhu were both unworthy—also just because of this single word 'arrogance,' which ruined their entire lives. You all should constantly reflect on this. The human mind is originally the natural Principle of Heaven, refined and clear, without the slightest stain or attachment. It is simply a 'no-self' and nothing more. In one's breast, there absolutely must not be anything—to have anything is arrogance. All the excellent qualities of the ancient sages were also simply 'no-self' and nothing more. No-self naturally leads to humility. Humility is the foundation of all good. Arrogance is the chief of all evil."

He further said: "This Way is utterly simple and easy, and also utterly refined and subtle. Confucius said: 'It is like showing the palm of one's hand.' People look at their palms every day—when have they not seen it? Yet if you ask them how many lines are in their palm, they do not know. It is the same with my two characters 'innate knowing.' Once explained, it is immediately clear—who does not understand? But if you want to truly see innate knowing, who can actually see it?"

Someone asked: "This knowing seems to be without form or substance—it is most difficult to grasp."

The Master said: "Innate knowing is the Changes itself: 'Its Way shifts and changes constantly, moving without fixity, circulating through the six positions, rising and falling without regularity, firm and yielding alternating—one cannot make it into a fixed model, but only adapt to changes as they come.' How could you grasp this innate knowing? When you see through it—that is sageness."

Someone asked: "Confucius said: 'Hui is no help to me.' Did the sage really expect assistance from his disciples?"

The Master said: "This was a sincere statement. This Way is originally inexhaustible. The more questions and challenges arise, the more its subtlety is revealed. The sage's words are originally comprehensive in themselves. But when someone with blockages in his mind raises a difficulty, the sage, stimulated by the challenge, expresses himself with even greater brilliance. With Yan Hui, who heard one thing and knew ten, and whose mind was utterly clear—how could there be any challenging questions? Therefore the sage too remained in tranquil immobility, with nothing to express. That is why he said 'no help.'"

Zou Qianzhi once told Dehong: "Shu Guoshang once held out a piece of paper and asked the Master to write out the chapter on 'a tree of only a handful's girth.' The Master took up his brush and wrote. When he reached the line 'as for one's own body, not knowing how to nourish it,' he turned and smiled: 'Guoshang, having passed the civil examinations and even won first place, surely he genuinely knows how the body ought to be nourished? Does he really need to recite this as a warning?' At that moment, all the friends in attendance were struck with awe."

Postscript by Qian Dehong:
In the winter of the wuzi year of Jiajing (1528), Dehong and Wang Ruzhong hastened to Guangxin upon news of the Master's death. They sent notices to fellow students, arranging that within three years the recorded sayings would be collected. Afterwards, fellow students from various places sent what they had recorded. Dehong selected those most relevant to the discussion of learning, combined them with his own private records, and obtained a certain number of entries. While residing in Wu, he was about to have them printed together with the Collected Writings. But he had to leave due to mourning, and it was not accomplished. At that time, lecturing on the learning was increasing in all directions, and since the fundamental teaching of the Master's school had been made clear, it seemed there was no need for additional printing, so the matter dropped from his mind. Last year, our fellow student Zeng Zicai Han obtained Dehong's handwritten copy, supplemented it with additional collected materials, named it the Recorded Sayings, and had it printed in Jing. Upon reading it, Dehong felt the original collection was not sufficiently refined, so he deleted the repetitions, trimmed the excess, and preserved one third of it, naming it the Continued Record of Instructions for Practical Living, and had it reprinted at the Shuixi Academy in Ningguo. This summer, Dehong came traveling to Qi. Shen Siwei said: "The Master's teaching has long been practiced in all directions, but has uniquely not reached Qi. The scholars of Qi, upon reading the Recorded Sayings, felt as if personally receiving the Master's instruction, with innate knowing pointed out as if seeing the light of sun and moon again. They fear only that the transmission might not be broad enough, and do not consider the repetitions a burden. Might we print the additional entries that were left out?" Dehong said: "Indeed, the Master's teaching of extending innate knowing and investigating things was meant to open the way for those who come to study. Students practiced in silence and verified it personally, not daring to receive it as mere intellectual understanding, but only through genuine personal realization. Therefore the Master spoke of it tirelessly all day long, and students listened tirelessly all day long. For when the guidance is single-pointed, personal realization grows daily more refined. Understanding is met before the words, and spirit is awakened beyond the words—this is the sincerity of the encounter of stimulus and response. Now, not yet three decades since the Master's passing, these essential words and subtle teachings are gradually falling into obscurity. Is this not because our group has not practiced them vigorously enough in our own persons, and excessive talk has contributed to the problem? It is because students pursue different directions and the Master's teaching is not propagated." So he took the remaining manuscripts, selected those whose language did not deviate from the teaching, and obtained one volume. The rest—those whose resonance was not authentic and those already included in the Collected Writings—were all deleted. He also reorganized the middle volume into a question-and-answer format, and entrusted it to the magistrate of Huangmei, Mr. Zhang, for additional printing. It is hoped that readers will not receive it as mere intellectual understanding but only through genuine personal realization—then there will be no doubts about this Record.

In the summer of the bingchen year of Jiajing (1556), the fourth month, the disciple Qian Dehong respectfully writes at the Chongzheng Academy in Qi.
